results.title: The Living planet. - Part 1: the building of the earth
results.brief_description: Part One of a two part series. From the sub zero temperatures of the polar ice-caps to the baking heat of the deserts, from the ash-strewn sides of a volcano to the dense vegetation of a tropical forest, the environments on Earth are no less remarkable than the variety of life itself and almost nowhere on our planet is devoid of life. Narrated by David Attenborough.

results.title: Joey: the autobiography of Joey Deacon (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Gibson, Peter Goodchild and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Joey Deacon, born in 1920 with brain damage, grew up severely spastic, unable to talk or walk. When, in 1928, his mother died, he was sent to an institution where he lived for years, quite unable to make himself understood. Then, in 1941, he met Ernie Roberts who had one remarkable skill - he could understand Joey. This led to a new and richer life, and this film tells Joey’s remarkable story. Based on Joey Deacon’s book “Tongue tied”.

results.title: China: times of silk and gold (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Professor William Watson, Professor of Chinese Art and Archaeology at the University of London, and Magnus Magnusson continue their journey across modern China, visiting one of the world’s great Buddhist shrines; the caves at Lyang; Sian, the ancient capital; and the tomb of a T’ang princess who died in 701 AD In the Forbidden City of Kubblah Khan in Peking, a remarkable clock is discovered - a present to the Emperor from Britain’s first trade mission in the 18th century.

results.title: Birth (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Part five of the series, “The Family of Man” which sets out to compare family life in five different locations around the world. In this programme, pregnancy, birth and attitudes of women in all five places are examined, with a side-long look at different superstitions which reveal some strange stories. The programme asks, “Do women in peasant countries give birth with less pain and effort? And if so, why?”

results.title: Long Shadows the Legacy of the American Civil War
results.brief_description: A documentary examining the legacy of the American Civil War and its effect upon the politics and people of the south in the 1980s. Interviews with Robert Penn Warren, Studs Terkel, Jimmy Carter and others.

results.title: Raiders of the top end
results.brief_description: A factual and exclusive account of the mainland activities of Exercise Kangaroo 89 which tested the ability of the Australian Defence Force to operate in and defend against terrorist style attack the vast, remote and sparsely populated region of Australia’s Top End. The program graphically captures the reality of how the threats and attacks by effective Kumarian enemy raiding parties were dealt with. It won a gold camera award and a certificate of creative excellence at the USA Film and Video Festival in Chicago 1990.

results.title: Stopping the coming ice age
results.brief_description: Probably the most important video many of us will ever see. Record cold winters and record summer heat and drought, increasing floods, hurricanes and tornadoes, dying forests, massive fuel burning and the clearcutting of the tropical rainforests are all related. The next Ice Age may be virtually upon us, a natural 100,000 year cycle driven by erosion, the death and rebirth of forests and the rise and fall of greenhouse gases. It has already resulted in massive starvation. If we act quickly we may be able to stop it, if not we may be eating less in seven years.

results.title: Sydney Harbour Bridge. Bondi. Sydney Bush. Cars
results.brief_description: A compilation of four experimental films made by filmmaker, Paul Winkler, between 1977 - 1980: “Sydney Harbour Bridge”, “Bondi”, “Sydney Bush” and “Cars”.

results.title: Ecology
results.creator_credit: Mal Tennant, Sandra Cleary and Julie Clarke
results.brief_description: Ecology is a far-sighted and exhilirating testament from a diverse but growing community of academics, scientists, futuristic thinkers and philosophers from around the world that points the way to an enlightened tomorrow. Rated: G
